body.name: The Man With Two Names: A Novel of Ancient Rome (The Sertorius Scrolls Book 1)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I just came across this and thought I would give it a try. I’m glad I did. What a fantastic book and I can’t wait to start the next one!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Novel Told from the Viewpoint...
reviews.reviewText: ... of a young, idealistic Sabine who wants to help the people of his impoverished village, province, and, of course, his family. Predictably, he becomes disillusioned with the corruption of his wealthy patron and has some hard choices to make: to rely on the dubious promises of his patron and enrich himself or to take the more difficult path and serve his patron's political adversary with honor.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A very good book
reviews.reviewText: This story takes the reader into the heart of the Roman Republic as seen by two young men from the country that become caught up in the political turmoil as different families fight to rule Rome. This lead the friends to join the Legion to get away from reprisals of one of the groups that used bribes and scare tactics to get what they want. The book follows the story of the men as they train to fight the enemies of Rome. The book tells the story of their battles in Gaul and the after effects that change their lives.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Typical military novel. The Roman setting makes it a little different. Unfortunately predictable. Women barely exist. He’s a good writer.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars On a scale of cotton candy to Brussels sprouts, The Man With Two Names by Vincent B. Davis is lightly salted asparagus spears.
reviews.reviewText: On a scale of cotton candy to Brussels sprouts, The Man With Two Names by Vincent B. Davis is lightly salted asparagus spears. Roasted in the oven, the asparagus becomes crispy and sharp. Not only are they good for you, but they're tasty, too.Quintus and Lucius leave their home town, Nursia, to seek purpose in Rome. Quintus goes in hopes of finding a patron to send food to Nursia, and Lucius plans to join the army. What they discover is a complicated political climate that threatens their own goals, and they must choose who to swear fealty to.Vincent B. Davis II brought the Roman time period to life for the modern reader. He captured the realities and ideals of the army, and appropriately so, since he has served his country as well, which I found out in the author bio. However, in a few instances, the story pacing jarred me right off the page, but I climbed back into the story to find out what would happen. Overall, I enjoyed experiencing Rome through Quintus and Lucius.If you are intrigued by Roman history, The Man With Two Names is for you.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars At last a new view of ancient Rome
reviews.reviewText: You may know there is an established literary genre for historical fictions, usually focusing on the Empire. There are several authors known to all fans of this time and place, all excellent reading; educational and entertaining. But, there is a cookie-cutter quality to all of these series.I applaud these Sertorious novels because they do not follow the beaten path. I do not need anymore lengthy, repetitive descriptions of human intestines spilling onto a warrior's lap. I am tired of the predictable subplot where the lady love is cruelly assasinated. I am tired of page filling descriptions of an age cleaving a man from skull to crotch.Mr. Davis, in his Stertotious novels, understands that when a reader asks for the time of day, he hasn't asked how to build a watch. I highly recommend these books by Vincent B. Davis II. You get the full story at a reasonable pace. Hasten Thy Story, someone said. I see Hemingway as a model for these fat-free historical fictions. Highly recommend.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love these Sertorius books
reviews.reviewText: I feel as if I were in Ancient Rome in these novels. Sertorious is a man with honor and courage, as well as doubts and weaknesses. If you love books set in history, this series is for you. The characters are all life-like and have the feel of authenticity - they are of their time, not ours. Vale! to the author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Politics, War, Love, Enemies
reviews.reviewText: The only problem I had with the novel was that I wanted to read more! I was so disappointed when I finished it because I wanted to find out about the rest of the story. This book tells us so much more of what it was like it ancient Rome. I found it very interesting as well as informative. I've read stories about Rome but this one drew me into it. Possibly because even though there is a main character, so many other characters added so much to the story line. In this novel there is plenty of mystery, intrigue, descriptions of political and military protocols and how they vied against each other. Many type of relationships that included brotherly love, romantic love, as well as the opposite in personal enemies as well as the enemies against Rome. Very good read.
An excellent continuation of a terrific adventure! A must for anyone who enjoys Roman and Barbarian battles and adventures!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 23, 2023
reviews.reviewText: My husband thoroughly enjoyed these books. The detail of the period is phenominal. Highly recommended.

I enjoyed getting lost among Imperators, consuls, legionnaires, Roman politics, warfare, customs, attitudes, et al. The Man With Two Names is an engrossing read for anyone interested in historical fiction.

I enjoyed this book very much. The historical research was excellent and the story was gripping. I really felt the emotions of the characters. I also found it interesting how much the political situation related to today.
Interesting plot with believable characters. I liked the political intrigue. A view into early Roman conquest and surrounding countries was enlightening.
